advert.description: <br><font color="red"><strong>> ADVERT #2</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to <a href="http://www.cobit.kit.net" target="_blank">COB-Clube Old Bits</a> for this picture.</p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT (APRIL 1982)</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> BROCHURE #3</strong></font><br><blockquote>Graphics examples of the optional graphic card.<p class="petitgris">Thanks to <b>Tim Mackay</b> </p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> QL CATALOGUE #5</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> GOLDSTAR 3DO MODEL ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to <a href="http://members.aol.com/djswaggle/3doad.html" target="_blank">3DO ads</a> for the picture</p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT (NOV. 1979)</strong></font><br><blockquote>This is the only SILEX advert known so far... <br><br> It says : "Silex, a stone in our competitors garden." <br><br> Silex means flint in french, a stone mainly used in prehistoric times as tools and weapons. </blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> ADVERT #1</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT (JAN. 1982)</strong></font><br><blockquote>"French people talking to french people"</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT #3</strong></font><br><blockquote>"With a cool teacher, computers is a child game" <br><br> "Alice, the Basic teacher"</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT (FEBRUARY 1982)</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> ADVERT #3 (1983)</strong></font><br><blockquote>In March 1983, the price of the assembled version decreased of $20 ($79.95 instead of $99.95)</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> U.S. ADVERT (1979)</strong></font><br><blockquote>Advert said:<br><br> <font color="#666666">You may not have thought of all the reasons for buying a personal computer. There are exciting games, of course, but what about financial management, household records, even income tax? You need a versatile, sophisticated machine that's as limitless as your imagination. You need the Compucolor ll...</font></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> U.S. AD (1983)</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> U.S. ADVERT #1 (1977)</strong></font><br><blockquote>The first Apple II advert.<br><br> Advert said:<br><br> <font color="#666666">Clear the kitchen table. Bring in the color TV. Plug in your new Apple ll and connect any standard cassette recorder / player. Now, you're ready for an evening of discovery in the new world of personal computers.<br> Only Apple ll makes it that easy. At $1298, it includes video graphics in 15 colors, 8KB ROM and 4KB RAM... It's the first personal computer with a fast version of BASIC permanently stored in ROM...<br><br> Apple ll is also available in board-only form to the do-it-yourself hobbyist. Has all of the features of the Apple ll system but does not include case, keyboard, power supply or game paddles. $598</font></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT (FEB. 1982)</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> ALTAIR 'MOBILE' COURSE</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to <b>Mark Thompson</b> </p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> US ADVERT, AUGUST 1983</strong></font><br><blockquote>From Personal Computing, August 1983 issue.<p class="petitgris">Courtesy of <b><a href="http://www.aci.com.pl/mwichary/" target="_blank">Attached</a></b></p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> U.S. AD #1 (1982)</strong></font><br><blockquote>Advert said:<br><br><font color="#666666"> We know your question: How could Olivetti have developped a better personal computer than the other giants?<br> The answer is in a word: Experience. Olivetti introduced the world's first desktop computer in 1965. Since then, we've continued to market a variety of minicomputers and microcomputers to a wide range of users...</font></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> MOTOROLA AD.</strong></font><br><blockquote>In fact, this advert didn't promote the Macintosh II computer but the 68020 microprocessor.<br> Advert said:<br><br><font color="#666666"> ...While Apple's choice of the MC 68020 was a smart move, there's no licence on genius: the 68020 is the microprocessor of choice in advanced business system design by such industry leaders as Altos, Alpha Micro, Casio, C.Itoh, Fujitsu, Honneywell Bull, NEC, NCR, Olivetti, Plexus, Ricoh, Sanyo, Sharp, TI, Toshiba and Unisys...</font></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> JUPITER BROCHURE #1</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> PROUD MOTHER</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> ADVERT #2</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Picture courtesy of <a href="http://www.sbrowning.com/vintage">Steve Browning, www.sbrowning.com/vintage</a>.</p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> UK ADVERT #2</strong></font><br><blockquote>Close-up of the previous advert showing the various cards of the Gemini 80-BUS system.</blockquote>
